Gee Whiz Everyone Wins Game: Finding Theoretical Probabilities

In the last five minutes of the Gee Whiz Everyone Wins! game show, several members of the audience are called to the stage. Each person chooses a block at random from a bucket containing an unknown number of red, yellow, and blue blocks. Each block has the same size and shape.

What do you think random means?

The contestants cannot see the blocks. Before choosing, the contestants predict the color of the block they will draw. If the prediction is correct, the contestant wins. After each selection, the block is put back into the bucket and the bucket is shaken.

Initial Challenge

Your class decides to play the Gee Whiz Everyone Wins! game using chips rather than blocks. You and your classmates will take turns. You will try to predict the color of the chip you select from the container that contains red, yellow, and blue chips.

Make a Prediction

  • Which color do you think will mostly likely occur?
Students might think that each color is equally likely. Some students may realize that there is no way to predict without more information â€“ it would just be a guess.

Conduct the Experiment

Equipment

  • Opaque container such as bucket, box, or bag
  • Various numbers of three different colors of chips (e.g., red, yellow, and blue) of the same size.
  • Note: The amount of each is only known by someone leading the experiment.

Directions (with the whole class or in large group)

Assign a leader to run the experiment. This person

  • allows the player to select a chip;
  • puts the chip back into the container, and stirs or shakes the chips in the container; and
  • gives the next player a turn.

Everyone else is considered a player.

  • Take turns one at a time.
  • Predict the color of the chip you will select from the container.
  • Without looking in the container, draw a chip out.
  • Record the color of the chip.
  • Return the chip to the container.
  • Repeat with the next player.

The experiment continues until 18 chips have been drawn and replaced.

Analyze the Data: Experimental Probability

  • Based on the data collected during the game, what is the experimental probability of choosing a red chip? Blue chip? Yellow chip?
Answers will vary depending on the data collected. Students may answer the questions based on their group data or on the classroom data.
• Would you rather be the first player or the last player? Explain.

The person to choose last from the bucket has the advantage because he or she has more information about what is in the bucket.

Note: Shaking the container helps to keep the outcomes random. Returning the chip makes the probability the same for each player.

Analyze the Data: Theoretical Probabilities

  • Examine the chips in the container. What is the theoretical probability of drawing a red chip? Blue chip? Yellow chip?

Based on 9 red, 6 yellow, and 3 blue chips, or an equivalent proportion of them, in the container:

P(Red): 9/18 or 1/2 of the chips

P(Yellow): 6/18 or 1/3 of the chips

P(Blue): 3/18 or 1/6 of the chips
• Are the outcomes of red, blue, and yellow equally likely? Explain why or why not.

Each color does not have the same chance of being chosen because the number of blocks is different for each color. There are more red blocks than there are yellow or blue blocks, so choosing the color red is more likely than choosing yellow or blue. Choosing blue is least likely.
• What is the theoretical probability of drawing a green chip?
This is an impossibility. P(green) = 0/18 or 0
• What is the theoretical probability of not drawing a red chip?
P(not red) = 9/18
Are the outcomes of red, blue, and yellow equally likely? Explain why or why not.

No.

Each chip has an equally likely chance of being chosen.

However, each color does not have the same chance of being chosen because the number of chips is different for each color. There are more red chips than there are yellow or blue chips, so choosing the color red is more likely than choosing yellow or blue. Choosing blue is least likely.
• How does theoretical probability compare to the experimental probability?
Answers will vary. Combining the class data may result in the experimental probability more closely equaling the theoretical probability.
